title: Diabetic Ulcers
subtitle: Understanding and Managing Diabetic Foot Ulcers
description: Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) are complex wounds that result from the combination of nerve damage (neuropathy) and poor circulation caused by elevated blood sugar levels. Learn about the silent progression of diabetic ulcers, prevention strategies, and evidence-based treatment approaches.

metadata.title: Diabetic Ulcers: Causes, Prevention & Treatment | WoundWise
metadata.description: Expert guidance on diabetic foot ulcers from Dr. Alvin May. Learn about neuropathy, vascular disease, prevention strategies, and evidence-based treatments for diabetic wounds.

riskFactors: Diabetic neuropathy (nerve damage) reducing foot sensation
warningSigns: Small cuts or blisters you don't feel
Skin discoloration on feet or toes
Wounds that don't heal within weeks
prevention: Control blood sugar levels within target range
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or injuries
Keep feet clean, dry, and moisturized
Wear well-fitting shoes with adequate support
Regular healthcare provider visits for foot exams

sections.heading: Why Diabetic Ulcers Develop
sections.content:
Sugar diabetes is a condition where elevated blood sugar levels cause slow, silent damage throughout the body. For some people, uncontrolled diabetes leads to heart disease or vision loss. For others, it damages the kidneys to the point of requiring lifelong dialysis. And for many, diabetes leads to foot ulcers, infections, and even amputations.

The challenge is that high blood sugar levels cause damage that goes largely unnoticed until it's often too late. There's typically no pain, no swelling, and no discomfort as the damage occurs. Historically, it has been difficult for patients to test blood sugar levels regularly. Medication regimens can be challenging to administer. Because there are no immediate warning signs and no easy management solutions, tissue damage from diabetes often occurs in silence, day by day, from the inside of the body out.

By the time the damage presents itself, significant harm has already been done: vision loss, heart damage, or deep, complicated infections have developed.

callouts.content: Diabetes is a systemic disease affecting nearly all tissues throughout your entire body. The elevated sugars are carried in circulating blood, and since blood circulates everywhere to provide oxygen and nutrients to all cells, all those cells are exposed to elevated sugar levels.

subsections.heading: The Progressive Nature of Diabetes
subsections.content:
Diabetes is a progressive disease. Without intervention to lower average sugar levels, the disease will continue to worsen until it causes cellular injury, disability, organ failure, or even tissue death. Diabetes is silent in nature and progressive in the damage it causes.

Many patients don't fully understand the danger because they either don't see their doctor regularly, don't realize how serious ignoring the diagnosis can be, or don't know how to overcome the many challenges of following treatment. Since the silent damage largely stays out of sight, the urgency to control diabetes often stays out of mind for many diabetics and prediabetics.

sections.heading: Microvascular Disease: The Root Cause
sections.content:
One of the main reasons diabetes causes such widespread damage is because it injures the small blood vessels and tiny capillaries of the body. These delicate vessels are where oxygen in the blood transfers from the bloodstream to organs and tissues. We call it the microvasculature—'micro' for small plus 'vasculature' for blood vessels.

Organs like your heart, lungs, kidneys, and skin use the oxygen and nutrients from blood to function properly. However, in diabetes, high sugar levels cause scarring, narrowing, and hardening of the microvasculature, leading to irreversible damage. All that damage affects future blood flow and limits oxygen delivery to end organs. Without a healthy, properly functioning microvasculature, oxygen simply cannot reach the organs that need it, and the organs themselves become damaged as well.

callouts.content:
Think of blood vessels as roads that transport blood throughout the body. Large blood vessels—like arteries and veins—are highways and turnpikes, efficiently carrying blood over long distances. However, smaller blood vessels and capillaries (microvasculature) are like city streets, delivering blood and oxygen to individual tissues and organs—kind of like an Uber driver delivering food to your home when you're hungry.

Now imagine driving through your town, but normal roadways are all damaged and detoured. Your once wide, open city streets are more like congested downtown traffic where cars move slowly and struggle to reach their destination. In diabetes, when this 'congestion' happens in the microvasculature, oxygen and nutrients don't reach tissues in time. Without enough oxygen, cells and organs cannot function well, leading to end-organ damage that only gets worse with time.

subsections.heading: Controlling Blood Sugar Protects Your Tissues
subsections.content:
Controlling your blood sugar is the single best way we have to limit the progression of end-organ damage and other complications of diabetes. When blood sugar is well managed, it reduces the scarring and narrowing of the microvasculature and helps protect and preserve tissues.

Organs everywhere can be affected by poor sugar control, including the eyes, kidneys, heart, and skin. This is why blood sugar management is critical in diabetes care.

sections.heading: Diabetic Neuropathy: The Silent Danger
sections.content:
Nerve damage (neuropathy) is a common complication of diabetes. When your nerves are affected, you may experience reduced or altered sensation in certain areas like your legs and feet. This lack of sensation makes it harder to detect injuries like cuts or blisters.

The elevated blood sugar levels in diabetes cause progressive and irreversible injury to nerves—particularly nerves responsible for sensation in the legs and feet. In medicine, we call this 'diabetic neuropathy,' but in everyday language it simply describes decreased or abnormal sensation in the skin when it comes to light touch, pressure, cuts, and even burns.

callouts.content:
Consider the case of Mr. Trumbull, a middle-aged man battling a persistent diabetic foot ulcer. Mr. T discovered the wound after noticing a large bright red spot staining the bottom of his sock one evening as he prepared for his nightly shower. Upon examination, he noticed a cut with a tiny piece of glass still partially buried below the skin.

As we chatted during his initial evaluation, he said, 'The weird thing, Doc, is the only time I was around broken glass was about a week ago when I broke a glass in the kitchen and had to sweep it up. I guess I should have been more careful.'

Until that point, Mr. T had not fully faced the extent to which his diabetes had compromised his ability to feel sensation in his feet. It was only the visual sight of the blood-stained sock that alerted him to the wound. The elevated sugar levels in his blood had damaged the nerves of his legs to the point where he was no longer able to feel a cut to his foot, much less the shard of glass that had found a home within the skin and soft tissues of his foot.

subsections.heading: How Neuropathy Leads to Ulcers
subsections.content:
Decreased ability to feel your feet puts you at risk of developing new and worsening ulcers. For example, if a shoe doesn't fit well, it could lead to excessive rubbing against certain areas of the foot and ankle without your knowledge, causing skin damage or ulcer formation. A lack of sensation could also cause you to disregard a small cut or an ingrown toenail you can't feel, allowing it to fester and worsen.

Similarly, unrealized reinjury and infection due to lack of sensation can cause complications and setbacks in the healing of known diabetic wounds. Because diabetic patients cannot feel pain that injuries should cause, wounds can fester and grow well beyond what they might have been had they been caught earlier.

callouts.content: Understanding Diabetic Neuropathy: The elevated blood sugar levels of diabetes affect systems throughout the body. In the nervous system, high sugars lead to damage or loss of the protective myelin sheath that covers, protects, and insulates nerve fibers (demyelination). In the body, myelin is like the rubber insulation around an electrical wire. When demyelination occurs, nerves may not work correctly, leading to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and weakness—particularly in the extremities.

sections.heading: The Perfect Storm: Neuropathy Plus Vascular Disease
sections.content:
When microvascular injury and nerve damage combine, areas like the feet become particularly vulnerable to ulcer formation for diabetics. Unlike someone who does not have nerve damage, a diabetic may not feel a small cut or new blister forming due to reduced ability to feel their feet. On top of this, that small injury will often fail to heal properly due to poor circulation caused by diabetic vascular disease.

It is this combination of conditions that leads to the deterioration and downward spiral of diabetic ulcers. A small injury goes ignored or untreated. It lingers. The wound then gets further injured due to everyday wear and tear from normal activities. The wound slowly gets bigger with time; all the while, the diabetic patient feels little to no discomfort from any of it. Inevitably, infection develops in the wound, further complicating things. It all creates a recipe for disaster.

callouts.content: Diabetic ulcers are notoriously complex and challenging to heal for several reasons: (1) Diabetes can affect blood vessels, decreasing blood flow, oxygen, and nutrients to the wound site. (2) Diabetic neuropathy can cause reduced sensation in the affected area, making patients less aware of developing problems. (3) High blood sugars affect the immune system by reducing the body's ability to fight bacteria and preventing wound infections, while promoting inflammation that limits the formation of new blood vessels to the wound. All of these challenges make diabetic ulcers particularly difficult to heal.

sections.heading: Prevention Strategies
sections.content:
People who have had diabetes for a long time or who have poorly controlled blood sugar levels are at the highest risk for diabetic ulcers. However, with proper care and awareness, diabetic ulcers can often be effectively treated or prevented.

Checking your feet regularly for cuts, blisters, or injuries—especially if you're experiencing reduced sensation—is essential. Daily foot inspection is one of the most important preventive measures you can take.

subsections.heading: Practical Prevention Strategies
subsections.content:
Here are evidence-based strategies for preventing diabetic ulcers and managing diabetic foot health:

**Blood Sugar Control**: Control blood sugar levels within the target range through diet, exercise, and medications as prescribed by your healthcare provider. This is the foundation of all diabetic ulcer prevention.

**Daily Foot Inspection**: Regularly inspect your feet for any cuts, blisters, or injuries, especially if you have reduced sensation. Use a mirror to check the bottoms of your feet if needed.

**Foot Hygiene**: Keep your feet clean and dry, and moisturize them to prevent cracks and dryness. However, avoid moisturizing between toes, as this can promote fungal infections.

**Proper Footwear**: Wear well-fitting shoes and consider using custom orthotic inserts to reduce pressure on specific areas. Never walk barefoot, even indoors.

**Smoking Cessation**: Avoid smoking, as it can impair blood flow and hinder wound healing. Smoking is one of the most significant modifiable risk factors.

**Professional Care**: Work closely with your healthcare provider to manage your diabetes and foot health. Regular professional foot exams are essential for early detection of problems.

callouts.content: Diabetic wounds are a consequence of the severity and duration of your diabetes. By being proactive and taking care of your overall health, you can significantly reduce the risk of diabetic ulcers as well as their potential complications. Prevention is always easier than treatment.

sections.heading: Treatment Approaches
sections.content:
For months, many patients struggle with the slow healing of diabetic foot ulcers, leaving them feeling confused and discouraged by the lack of progress. The key is to understand that diabetes is a systemic disease where elevated sugar levels cause damage to cells throughout the body. High sugar levels in the blood affect normal wound healing in multiple ways.

Successful treatment requires a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach that addresses all aspects of the condition.

subsections.heading: Comprehensive Wound Care
subsections.content:
Proper diabetic ulcer treatment involves several key components:

**Offloading Pressure**: Using specialized footwear, custom orthotics, or walking boots to remove pressure from the ulcer is critical. Continued pressure on a diabetic ulcer prevents healing.

**Wound Debridement**: Regular removal of non-viable tissue by your wound care provider helps promote healthy granulation tissue growth.

**Infection Control**: Prompt recognition and treatment of infection is essential. Diabetic ulcers are highly susceptible to infection due to impaired immune function.

**Moisture Balance**: Appropriate wound dressings maintain optimal moisture levels. Too dry or too wet environments both impair healing.

**Blood Sugar Management**: Maintaining blood sugar levels within target range is the foundation of all treatment. Without good glucose control, even the best local wound care may fail.

**Vascular Assessment**: In some cases, poor circulation may require vascular intervention to restore blood flow before healing can occur.

subsections.heading: Working with Your Healthcare Team
subsections.content:
Effective diabetic ulcer treatment requires coordination among multiple healthcare providers. Your team may include:

- Wound care specialist or podiatrist for local wound management
- Endocrinologist for diabetes control
- Vascular surgeon if circulation issues need intervention
- Infectious disease specialist if complicated infections develop
- Certified diabetes educator for lifestyle management
- Physical therapist for mobility and offloading strategies

Open communication with your entire healthcare team is essential for optimal outcomes. Report any changes in your wound, even small ones, immediately to your providers.

faqs.question: Why didn't I feel my diabetic foot ulcer developing?
faqs.answer: Diabetic neuropathy causes progressive damage to the nerves responsible for sensation in your feet. This nerve damage means you may not feel cuts, blisters, pressure, or even burns that would normally alert you to injury. That's why daily visual foot inspection is so critical—you can't rely on pain to warn you of problems.

faqs.question: How long does it take for a diabetic ulcer to heal?
faqs.answer: Healing time varies significantly depending on the ulcer's size, depth, location, infection status, and—most importantly—your blood sugar control. Small, superficial ulcers may heal in weeks with proper care and good glucose control. However, deeper ulcers or those complicated by infection or poor circulation may take months to heal. Some chronic diabetic ulcers may require advanced therapies or surgical intervention.

faqs.question: Can I prevent diabetic ulcers if I already have neuropathy?
faqs.answer: Yes! Even with existing neuropathy, you can significantly reduce your risk of ulcers through diligent prevention strategies. Daily foot inspection, proper footwear, meticulous foot hygiene, blood sugar control, and regular professional foot exams are all effective preventive measures. The key is compensating for your reduced sensation with heightened visual awareness and protective behaviors.

faqs.question: What's the connection between my A1C and wound healing?
faqs.answer: Your A1C reflects your average blood sugar levels over the past 2-3 months. Elevated A1C indicates prolonged exposure to high blood sugar, which damages blood vessels, impairs immune function, and disrupts normal healing processes. Studies show that wounds heal significantly better when A1C is well-controlled (generally below 7%). Working with your endocrinologist to optimize your A1C is one of the most important things you can do to promote diabetic ulcer healing.

faqs.question: Why do diabetic ulcers often get infected?
faqs.answer: Diabetic ulcers are highly prone to infection for several reasons: (1) High blood sugar impairs white blood cell function, reducing your body's ability to fight bacteria. (2) Poor circulation limits the delivery of immune cells and antibiotics to the wound. (3) Neuropathy prevents you from feeling early warning signs of infection. (4) The wound environment often contains devitalized tissue that provides a breeding ground for bacteria. This is why infection control and early detection are critical components of diabetic ulcer management.
